author: Leo Schlink in St Andrews
title: British Open 2015: Marc Leishman surges into share of second with stunning third round |
text:
THREE months after almost quitting golf as his wife battled for life, Marc Leishman has made a sensational charge at the Open Championship, surging into a share of second place with a fabulous third-round 64.
Leishman, 31, revealed he would have retired from golf to become a full-time carer for his two young sons Oliver and Harvey if his wife Audrey had not beaten the odds and survived acute respiratory syndrome.
Told in March Audrey had less than a five per cent chance of living as she lay in hospital on a ventilator, Leishman steeled himself for the worst.

PRAISE: Tiger endorses Day’s hopes at Open
His wife is now on the road to back to health after making a miraculous recovery — and Leishman is in contention to lift his first major after posting the lowest round of the week on the Old Course.
Leishman tees off on the 18th hole at St Andrews. Source: AP
“It was a huge possibility that I wasn’t going to be playing golf anymore,” Leishman said.
“Travelling with a one-year-old and a three-year-old by yourself ... well, it wasn’t going to happen. I wouldn’t do that to the boys
“At the time it was just, ‘Righto, you’re going to have to give it away and stay home with the boys and be a dad’, and that was the most important thing, and I was all right with that.
“Obviously the outcome, Audrey is all right now and it’s a lot better. It’s great that she’s healthy again.
“But yeah, that was pretty rough there for a while, thinking about everything, the boys not growing up with their mum, me not playing golf anymore, not having a wife.
“It was just everything. Unfortunately it probably happens every day to people around the world. We were just really lucky that she’s on the mend.”
Leishman said he would dedicate an Open victory to his wife.
“Obviously it would be massive,” he said. “That’s the goal now. Today the goal was to shoot a good round and get myself so I had a chance tomorrow (Monday AEST).
“It would be great to get a hold of that trophy and nice to take it back for Audrey and the boys.
“But there’s obviously a lot that has to happen between now and Monday night to do that. But that would be awesome.

Paired with fellow Victorian Marcus Fraser, Leishman started the day at one-under before drilling birdies at the fourth, fifth, seventh, eighth, 10th, 11th, 13th, and 15th to soar up the leaderboard.
His sensational round left him only a shot behind American Dustin Johnson (10-under) alongside England’s Danny Willett
Leishman could easily have deposed Johnson in the overall lead if not narrow misses on the 16th and 17th, where birdie putts slipped agonisingly past the lip of the cup.
Leishman’s extraordinary round catapulted him past Queenslanders Adam Scott and Jason Day, who started the third round locked at seven-under.
Several Australians have massed near the top of the leaderboard with Steven Bowditch, Geoff Ogilvy and Fraser also in contention at five-under.
An established performer at the elite level, Leishman boasts two previous top-five results at the majors — fourth at the 2013 US Masters won by Scott and fifth in last year’s Open Championship.
Marc Leishman has surged into contention at the Open. Source: AP
Revelling in the still conditions on greens softened by overnight rain, Leishman’s positioning and iron play was immaculate.
He repeatedly left himself with makeable birdie chances as rain returned to the Old Course for the delayed third round.
His only blunder came at the par-five 14th when a rare approach shot failed to hit its target — yet he still managed a comfortable par.
Fraser also impressed without being rewarded on the scorecard.
John Senden improved to four-under while Matt Jones had climbed to six-under early in his third round.
After Friday and Saturday’s weather extremes — rain and wind conspired for delays totally 14 hours to force a Monday finish — the third round was positively benign.
And almost from the start of play, the leaderboard ran red with birdies.
Playing with Sydney’s Scott Arnold, 2001 Open champion David Duval led the barrage with six birdies in a five-under round 67.
Arnold was disappointed wit his one-over 73 after a brilliant effort to make the cut on Saturday with a string of birdies in high winds.
US Open winner Jim Furyk hammered home six birdies to climb to a tie of 13th, only four shots from the lead.
Englishman Eddie Pepperell (eight-under) and American Rickie Fowler (seven-under) were others to capitalise on the pristine conditions to make their moves.
Originally published as Leishman storms into contention at Open
